questions.question_text: A system of simultaneous linear equations is given by 2x + 3y = 5, 4x + ky = 7. There will be a unique solution only when
questions.detailed_answer:
Method 1: There is no unique solution when the gradients are equal, i.e. when k = 6. Therefore, there is a unique solution when k ≠ 6. The answer is D.
Method 2: As a matrix equation, this system can be written as [[2,3],[4,k]] [x,y]^T = [5,7]^T. There will be no solution or infinite solutions when det = 2k - 12 = 0, i.e. k = 6. When k = 6, the system becomes inconsistent. There will be a unique solution when k ≠ 6. The answer is D.

questions.question_text: Let A and B be two independent events from a sample space where P(A) = 0.5 and P(B) = 0.6. P(A ∪ B) is equal to
questions.detailed_answer: Since A and B are independent P(A ∩ B) = P(A)P(B) = 0.3. P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A ∩ B) = 0.5 + 0.6 - 0.3 = 0.8. We are told that P(A ∪ B) = x. Solving for x gives x = 0.8, so P(A ∪ B) = 0.8. Note that P(A ∪ B) cannot be greater than 1. The answer is C.

questions.question_text: The tangent to the graph of y = x³ - 3x is parallel to the line with equation y = 6x - 1 at particular points on the graph. Which one of the following gives all the possible values of x at these points?
questions.detailed_answer: Solve for x where y' = 6: 3x² - 3 = 6 → x² = 3 → x = ±√3. Two of these options are given in option D but two are missing and we are asked for all the possible values of x, so eliminate option D. Note that √3 ≈ 1.732. Solve 3x² - 3 = 6. We require x ∈ [-2, 2] or alternatively, |x| ≤ 2, because we need a solution in each quadrant. So x = ±√3. The answer is A.

questions.question_text: Let f(x) = x⁴ - 4x² + 3. The graph of y = f(x + k) has two or more stationary points with positive x-coordinates. Which one of the following is not a possible value of k?
questions.detailed_answer: Sketch the graph of f. The graph of y = f(x - k) translates the graph of f k units to the right when k is positive. It translates the graph of f k units to the left when k is negative. For there to be at least two stationary points with positive x-coordinates, the graph of f can be translated up to 11.03… units to the left. Any further left and there will be less than two stationary points with a positive x-coordinate. In other words, how far left can we translate the graph of f so that two of its stationary points remain to the right of the y-axis? We require |k| < √3 + 1 ≈ 2.732. Since k = -3 is not a possible value of k. The answer is A.

questions.question_text: The probability density functions of two normal random variables X and Y are respectively f(x) and g(y). The means of X and Y are both zero and the standard deviation of X is half the standard deviation of Y. A transformation y = ax maps the graph of f onto the graph of g, where g(y) = (1/a) f(y/a). The values of a and b could be
questions.detailed_answer: A normal distribution is a continuous probability distribution so P(X = 0) = 0. Reject option A. The standard deviation of X is half the standard deviation of Y or alternatively put, the standard deviation of Y is twice the standard deviation of X. Therefore, the graph of f will be dilated from the y-axis by a factor of 2 to become the graph of g. So a could equal 2. Option B is the only option that satisfies these requirements for b. The answer is B.

questions.detailed_answer:
a. Let T be a normally distributed variable with μ = 0, σ = 5. P(|T| < 2) = 2Φ(2/5) - 1 = 0.9772 (correct to 4 decimal places). (1 mark)
b. or alternatively, P(T > k) = 0.05. Using the inverse normal function on CAS, k = invNormal(0.95, 0, 5) ≈ 7.653. So k ≈ 7.653 (correct to 3 decimal places). (1 mark)
c. i. The manager models a binomial distribution with parameters n = 6, p = 0.5. ( binomPdf(6,0.5,2) = 0.234375) ( binomPdf(6,0.5,3) = 0.3125) ( binomPdf(6,0.5,5) = 0.09375) (1 mark) for one correct point (1 mark) for all points correct
ii. P is a binomially distributed variable with parameters n = 6, p = 0.5. P(X ≥ 1) = 1 - binomPdf(6,0.5,0) = 0.9844 (correct to 4 decimal places). (1 mark)
iii. P(X ≤ 4 | X ≥ 1) = P(1 ≤ X ≤ 4) / P(X ≥ 1) = [1 - P(X = 0) - P(X = 5) - P(X = 6)] / 0.9844 ≈ 0.9219 (correct to 4 decimal places). (1 mark) (1 mark)
d. i. Var(X) = E(X²) - [E(X)]² = (0²*0.8 + 1²*m + 2²*n) - (m + 2n)² = 4n + m - (m + 2n)² = 3m + 2n (since m + n = 0.2). (1 mark) (1 mark) (formula sheet) (1 mark)
ii. The graph of the function defining the variance is part of an inverted parabola. From the table, 0 ≤ m ≤ 0.2. This is the domain of the variance function. The maximum variance therefore occurs when m = 0.1. The maximum variance is therefore 0.3 or 0.3. (1 mark)
e. i. Margin of error = (0.2248 - 0.1752)/2 = 0.0248. z ≈ 1.96 for 95%. ˆp ≈ 0.2, ˆsd(ˆp) = 0.0248 / 1.96 ≈ 0.0127 (correct to 4 decimal places). (1 mark) (1 mark)
ii. New width = old width / 4 = 0.0496 / 4 = 0.0124. New margin = 0.0062. n = (1.96 * ˆsd(ˆp) / 0.0062)² ≈ 10000. (1 mark) (1 mark)

b. Do a quick sketch. Area = ∫_0^3 (√(x + 1) - 1/x) dx = [ (2/3)(x + 1)^{3/2} - ln|x| ]_0^3 = ( (2/3)*8 - ln3 ) - ( 2 - 0 ) = 16/3 - ln3 - 2 = 10/3 - ln3. (1 mark) (1 mark) Note, because you haven’t been asked to express your answer correct to a certain number of decimal places, you must leave your answer as an exact value.
c. i. h(x) = f(g(x)) = 1/√(x + 1). (1 mark)
ii. Domain: x ≥ -1. Range: h(x) > 0 so (0, ∞). (1 mark) (1 mark)
iii. Now make y the subject. y = 1/√(x + 1) → √(x + 1) = 1/y → x + 1 = 1/y² → x = 1/y² - 1. h⁻¹(x) = 1/x² - 1. (1 mark)
d. By inspection, it is seen that the graphs of h and y = x intersect on the line y = 1, so the point of intersection is (1, 1). The average value of the function is (1/p) ∫_0^p h(x) dx. So required average value expression (1/p) [ ∫_0^1 h(x) dx + ∫_1^p h(x) dx ] = (1/p) ∫_0^p h(x) dx. (1 mark)
e. Solve using CAS. We require y = 1. So Q is the point (3, 1/2). (1 mark) Gradient = h'(3) = d/dx [1/√(x + 1)] at x = 3 = -1/(4 (x + 1)^{3/2}) at x = 3 = -1/32. (1 mark)
f. Let θ be the angle that the tangent to h at Q makes with the positive branch of the x-axis. Using our answer to part e., tan θ = -1/32. We require |θ| < π/6. tan(π/6) = 1/√3 ≈ 0.577. Since |tan θ| < 0.577, |-1/32| < 1/√3. 1/32 < 1/√3. a > √3 / 32 * something wait, but (given in question) so a > 0. (1 mark) Using CAS but (given in question) so a > 0. (1 mark)

questions.question_text: Let f(x) = sin(π x / 3) + sin(2 π x). Part of the graph of f is shown below.
questions.detailed_answer:
a. The period of sin(π x / 3) is 6. The period of sin(2 π x) is 1. It is required that the graphs of the two functions above simultaneously repeat. Therefore, the least common multiple of 6 and 1 is required, and the least common multiple is 6. Therefore, the graphs of the two functions simultaneously repeat after 6 units. The period of f is therefore 6. (1 mark)
b. Graph f on your CAS. Make sure that the coordinates of the points on the graph are expressed to at least 4 decimal places on your CAS. One of the maximums occurs at x ≈ 1.4184, y ≈ 1.8787. So the maximum value of f is 1.879, correct to 3 decimal places. (1 mark)
c. To obtain the graph of y = -f(x + c), the graph of f is translated c units to the left (since c is positive) and then reflected in the x-axis. The smallest positive value of c for which the graph of y = -f(x + c) will coincide with the graph of f is c = 3. For example, the point (3, 0) on the graph of f becomes the point (0, 0) on the graph of y = -f(x + 3). So c = 3. (1 mark)
d. Solve ∫_0^q |f(x)| dx = 0, but actually find where net area is zero: ∫_0^q f(x) dx = 0. The smallest possible value of q is 10.73 (correct to two decimals places). (1 mark) (1 mark)
e. The period of sin(π (x + b) / 3) is 6. The period of sin(2 π (x + b)) is 1. The least common multiple is 6. So the period of the functions is 6. (1 mark)
f. i. The maximum value of g(x) = sin(π x / 3) + sin(2 π x + b) occurs at x = 3a/2. (1 mark)
ii. The maximum value of h(x) = sin(π (x + a) / 3) + sin(2 π x) occurs at x = 3(a - 1)/2. (1 mark)
g. For g(x) + h(x) = 2, we would require that the maximum value of g, which is 2, occurred at the same x value as where the maximum value of h, which is also 2, occurred at. Therefore, we would require that 3a/2 = 3(a - 1)/2 which leads to 0 = -3/2, contradiction. Now a is odd and b is even therefore a + b is never an integer for integer a, b, therefore (a + b)π is never a perfect square, therefore a is never a positive integer. Therefore, the maximum value of g + h cannot be 2. (1 mark) (1 mark)
